banner.text: OK... Your guitar is almost complete! Now let's animate the strings.

Lists are a way of storing lots of variables in a single place.
So let's create one. Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block

Change item to stringOffsets.
StringOffsets refers to how much each string shakes.

You need to set the variable as a list.
Open the Lists tray.

This block creates a new list.
Drag it onto your code space.
Connect it to the variable

Ok, now you need some starting values.
Open the Variables tray.

This means all the list values will start at 0.
Drag it onto your code space...
Connect it to this block

Now, choose how long the list will be.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 5... that's 5 list items for the 5 strings.

Now let's add shake to the strings with random.
Open the Math tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block

Look at them shake!
This is the effect you want, but only when the string is strummed.

Use the list you made earlier to shake the strings when they're played.
Open the Lists tray.

This block will read variables from the list.
Drag it onto your code space.
Connect it to this block

Now, tell it which list to read.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringOffsets.The code will use the list you set up.

Let's use the stringNumber variable to know which string is being drawn.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringNumber
They stopped shaking... but this just means we have more control!

Now, let's change the list each time a sound is played.
Open the Lists tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block. It will activate with the first string.
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringOffsets to access the list

Nice! Now choose which string to animate.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block

Let's animate the first string!
Change 0 to 1.

Now, set how much each string should vibrate.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 50 so it shakes by 50 pixels

Put your hand over the sensor and strum the strings...
Does the top one shake?

Great! Don't worry, you'll make it stop shaking later.
Let's set up the others first.

This bit is going to repeat a lot of code - let's see if we can do it quickly.
Open the Lists tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringOffsets
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 2 for the second string
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 50 to shake by 50 pixels
3 more! Open the Lists tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringOffsets
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 3 for the third string
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 50.
Almost there! Open the Lists tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringOffsets
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 4 for the fourth string
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 50 to shake it by 50 pixels
1 left! Open the Lists tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringOffsets
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 5 for the final string
Open the Variables tray
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 50 to shake it!

Nice! Put your hand over the sensor again... all the strings are shaking!
Let's make them stop shaking as the sound fades.

Let's access the stringOffsets list again.
Open the Lists tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block

You need to reference each string in the loop, to stop them all.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringOffsets

Reference each string in the loop again.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringNumber to reference each string and make the shake stop.

Great! You've nearly finished your !
Let's soften the shake with a math block. Open the Math tray.
Drag the block onto your code space...
...and connect it to this block.
Change + to multiply.

You need to reference the current value again.
Open the Lists tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block

Nice... Now reference your stringOffsets list again.
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringOffsets

Also, you need to know which string you're drawing!
Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change item to stringNumber
Now let's grab a number. Open the Variables tray.
Drag the block onto your code space
Connect it to this block
Change 0 to 0.9, so the shake gets smaller every frame.

You did it!
Put your hand over the sensor and play your guitar... see how the strings wobble and shake!
That was awesome. Why not change the sounds that play when the strings are strummed, maybe make an electric guitar  or drums?
